The direct conversion of methane to methanol over iron and cobalt oxide based composite catalysts supported over HZSM-5 was carried out in a fixed-bed micro reactor under changing process parameters and catalyst compositions. The prepared catalysts were well characterized by various techniques including N2 adsorption desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), pyridine FTIR, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), UV–vis spectroscopy and temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR). The characterization results revealed the presence of various reducible iron and cobalt oxide species depending on the Fe/Co molar ratio and total metal oxide loading. Moreover, the XPS and UV–vis spectroscopic results also confirmed the variation of Fe2+/Fe3+ and Co2+/Co3+ species depending on the Fe-Co molar ratio which had strong influence on the performance of the composite catalysts. It was found that the cobalt species favours the formaldehyde formation whereas the iron species promotes the formic acid formation in their respective pure supported oxide catalysts. However, the synergistic effect of iron and cobalt oxide in equimolar ratio in composite catalysts appeared as effective for achieving highest yield of methanol. The methanol selectivity was also influenced by the alteration of various studied process parameters. The higher reaction temperature favoured the overoxidation of methanol to CO2 whereas the methanol selectivity increased with increasing the methane to oxygen ratio. The lattice to adsorbed oxygen ratio also had strong influence on the activity of composite catalysts and methanol selectivity. The highest methanol yield of 1.87% was achieved at the methane conversion of 42.81 % with the 20Fe1Co1Z catalyst at 873 K reaction temperature with CH4/O2 ratio of 2:1 and WHSV of 1030 ml hr−1 gcat−1. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methane Methanol Fe-Co catalyst X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Lattice to adsorbed oxygen ratio Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Technological, socio economic and industrial development have been directly and or indirectly fueled by fossil fuels (coal, crude oil and natural gas) as sources of energy or commodity chemicals. Over the years the world has seen huge growth and evolution in the use of fossil fuel and proved their dominance in the global energy system [1]. Despite the prominent dependence of society on fossil fuels, they too have been associated with negative impacts and are largest contributors to climate change by releasing tremendous amount of carbon dioxide into nature. However, due to limited crude oil resource, natural gas has been proved to be an alternative for world's transition away from use of petroleum resources. According to Global Energy Outlook 2019 by IEA, proven world natural gas reserves were specified for the year 2018 to 198.8 trillion cubic meters and are abundant sources of methane [2]. However recent advancement in hydraulic fracturing made easy the access of methane rich shale gas reserves that are rich in methane (>70 % of the carbon) [3]. Natural gas consisting of approximately 70–90 % of methane is associated with challenges of storing and transporting from remote places [4]. Hence, it becomes difficult to make the prices of methane derived chemicals and fuels competitive to other fossils products. These challenges led to flaring of huge amounts of natural gas causing CO2 emissions. Thus, a valuable industrial feedstock natural gas (methane) being wasted needs to be utilized in an efficient way. Methane is considered as an important feedstock for the production of hydrocyanic acid (HCN), chlorinated methane derivatives (e.g., CH3Cl and CCl4), and CS2 [5] at industrial scale and as well as other worthful oxygenated products such as formaldehyde, formic acid and methanol. While on other hand methanol being a valuable chemical feedstock is used to produce biodiesel and other chemicals such as acetic acid, formaldehyde, MTBE etc. [6]. Hence utilizing the abundant resource methane and developing the technologies for an alternate fuel and feedstock for many industrial chemicals (e.g. methanol) can solve the global issues of both environment and economy in an efficient way by setting up a best example of waste to wealth. Conventionally, methane to methanol is produced by an indirect two steps route via syngas production through steam reforming followed by catalytic conversion using ZnO/Cr2O3 and CuZnO/Al2O3 catalysts, respectively [7]. This route is highly energy dependent with 65 % of thermodynamic efficiency operated at high temperature of around 1073–1273 K. Hence from sustainable development point of view direct conversion of methane to methanol (DMTM) is a desired alternative to this technology. Several technologies have been studied for DMTM including plasma technologies, photo catalysis, supercritical water oxidation, membrane technology, direct one step catalytic conversion (involving both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis) and bio catalysis [8]. Researchers are also trying to mimic the active sites of methane monooxygenase enzymes inspired from methanotrophic bacteria which can convert methane to methanol at room temperature [9–12]. However, the difficulty of DMTM process lies in the activation of methane molecule as dissociation energy of CH bond in methane is 440 kJ/mole which requires extreme reaction conditions for activation. On the other hand methanol activates easily under these conditions and oxidises to produce HCHO and COx, reducing the selectivity of desired product methanol [4]. Thus this route has been refereed as ‘holy grail’ by researchers [13]. Hence to overcome these challenges, development of an efficient catalysts is utmost necessary. Several catalysts including transition metal oxide ions (MO+ where M = Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Mo, Zn and Cu), noble metals (Pd, Au, Rh, Pt) and their combination were investigated with an aim of low temperatures partial oxidation of methane to methanol [14–18]. Several noble metals including bimetallic (Au-Pd/TiO2) and trimetallic catalysts (Cu-Au-Pd/TiO2) have been investigated [19–23] and found to have good catalytic activity at low temperature. However, the cost of noble metal limits their application at large scale and disturbs the economics of the process. Hence, focus of the researchers is shifted to reducing the content of noble metals in catalysts or developing non-noble metal-based catalysts for making the catalysts more cost effective for transformation of methane to methanol. Among the first- row transition metals, the oxides of Fe and Cu are extensively studied and found to be active for DMTM than rest of the metals. However, the cobalt-based catalysts have been mechanistically less understood. Studies using Fe modified HZSM5 and NaZSM5 catalysts revealed that the rate of methanol formation is more than CO2 over NaZSM-5 support with a methane conversion of less than 1 % [24]. In order to restrict deep oxidation of methane/methanol, the quasi-catalytic mode of reaction is also studied using Fe-ZSM5 and N2O as oxidant [25]. In another study, the Fe-ZSM5 catalysts studied for partial oxidation of methane using H2O2 as oxidant. It was concluded that the cationic μ-oxo-hydroxo species located at exchange sites in Fe-ZSM-5 promotes H2O2 mediated oxidation of methane to produce methanol [26]. In Fe containing MFI zeolites, it was reported that Brønsted acid sites are effective for selective oxidation of methane with N2O. However, the specific role of Brønsted acid sites is still debatable [18]. Apart from MFI framework, various other frameworks of zeolites modified with Cu were studied including MOR, FER, CHA, FAU, BEA, LTL, EON, MAZ, MEI, BPH, HEU, SZR, AFX and AEI [27–31]. Among these zeolites, Cu modified ZSM-5, and MAZ exhibited superior performance. Various efforts have been made to raise the methane conversion and methanol selectivity using Fe based catalysts [26,32–36], and Co modified zeolite [21]. Fe-based catalysts proved to be beneficial in enhancing the catalytic activity leading to rise in methane conversion [37]. A previous study using Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst in an aqueous medium with H2O2 as an oxidizing agent showed the formation of methanol and played an important role in the CH bond activation of methane. However, the primary product was methyl hydroperoxide [34]. It was also observed that Fe cations were responsible for enhancing oxygenates productivity [33]. In case of Co modified zeolites two main products were formed such as methanol and formaldehyde. Cobalt oxide species, Co3O4 and CoO in zeolite are selective for the formation of methanol. Whereas Co2+ species within the zeolite channel are responsible for the formation of formaldehyde [38]. However, few studies have been reported using cobalt as active metal oxide for DMTM [39–41]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations showed that less energy is required for CH bond activation in methane and methanol desorption for Co and Fe than Cu [42]. The zeolites affect the reactivity of active sites in metal exchanged zeolite catalysts taking into account of some key aspects including zeolites confinement, geometry and hydrogen affinity of active sites [38]. Based on the above discussion, the major challenges of DMTM process can be addressed through the development of efficient catalysts which are promising for activating the methane molecule at relatively lower reaction temperature and limiting the over oxidation of methanol to HCOOH and CO2. Several transition metal oxides, and noble metals catalysts and their combination were studied for partial oxidation of methane to methanol with an aim to achieve high yield of methanol. However, the CH bond activation in methane and methanol desorption are the two major challenges in achieving the high conversion and selectivity of desired product (methanol). Above discussion based on literature suggests that Fe cations are responsible for enhancing oxygenated selectivity. Whereas cobalt oxide species, Co3O4 and CoO in zeolites are selective for the formation of methanol. Moreover, the theoretical study involving DFT calculations showed that less energy is required for CH bond activation in methane and methanol desorption for Co and Fe than Cu based catalysts. Hence the present investigation focuses on translating mono metal oxide catalysts to composite metal oxides catalysts systems consisting of Fe and Co supported over HZSM-5 and study their synergistic effect for DMTM conversion. The activity of various Fe-Co composite catalysts supported on HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 23) was studied using fixed bed reactor considering influence of different process parameters. The Fe-Co composite catalysts of different Fe/Co molar ratio and total metal loading were well characterized using different characterization methods to understand the structural and physicochemical properties and surface-active sites. The characterization results and the activity data collected under studied reaction conditions were correlated to understand the mechanistic aspect and establish structure property relationship. 2 Experimentation 2.1 Materials HZSM-5 zeolite (SiO2/Al2O3 = 23, CBV2314) was procured from Zeolyst International, USA. Iron (III) nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3, 9H2O) (purity ≥ 98 %) and cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2, 6H2O) (purity ≥ 98 %) metal precursors were procured from Sigma-Aldrich. High purity methane gas (99.99 % purity) and oxygen gas (purity 99.99 %) were used in the present investigation. HZSM-5 was thermally treated at 823 K for 6 h prior to use and rest of the chemicals were utilized as incurred. 2.2 Catalysts preparation Several ZSM-5 (Zeolyst, SiO2/Al2O3 = 23) supported iron (Fe), cobalt (Co) and their composite metal oxides catalysts were prepared by following wetness impregnation method. The respective metal precursors solution was made by dissolving known quantity of respective metal precursors in millipore water. The precursor solution was then mixed with already pre-treated definite amount of HZSM-5 and stirred for sufficient time to ensure proper mixing. The wet material was kept for drying overnight at 393 K in a hot air oven. The pre-treatment of HZSM-5 was performed following the identical procedure of catalyst preparation with pure water only. The oven dried material was thoroughly ground to powder and placed in a muffle furnace for calcination at 823 K for 6 hr with a heating rate of 1 K min−1. The calcined catalysts are designated as xFeaCobZ where ‘x’ denotes wt.% of total metal loading (x = 5, 10, 15, 20 and 25 wt.%) whereas ‘a’ and ‘b’ denotes molar ratio of Fe and Co metals, and Z represents HZSM-5. 2.3 Catalyst characterisation The specific BET surface area and pore size distribution (PSD) of prepared catalysts were estimated using N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm data collected at 77 K in a physisorption analyser (Micromeritics ASAP2020, USA). Prior to N2 physisorption studies, all the catalysts were degassed at 473 K for 5 h. The multipoint Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) equation and adsorption isotherm data collected in the relative pressure (P/P0) range of 0.05–0.3 were considered for the estimation of specific surface area. Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was employed for the estimation of PSD whereas the micropore area and volume of the prepared catalysts were estimated using t-plot method. The liquid nitrogen volume adsorbed at P/Po = 1.0 (approx.) was reported as the pore volume of the concerned catalysts. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the xFeaCobZ catalysts were acquired in the 2θ range of 10 to 90° using a scan rate of 2° min−1 in a Rigaku Smart Lab, Japan X-ray diffractometer equipped with monochromatized Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) source and D/teX ultra 250 detector. The diffractometer was operated at 45 kV voltage and 30 mA current during data acquisition. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopic studies were carried out under ambient condition using Bruker Tensor 37, Germany FITR spectrometer. The IR spectral data were collected in transmission mode under ambient condition against KBr background in the wavenumber range of 400–4000 cm−1 with averaging of 256 no. of scans and a spectral resolution of 4 cm−1. Prior to data acquisition, a transparent pellet was made with the mixture of finely powdered catalyst and KBr of spectroscopic grade. To understand the nature of acid sites available in the prepared catalysts, the IR spectra were acquired with the pyridine treated catalysts following previously mentioned procedure. Prior to acquiring the spectra, a few drops of pyridine were added and kept for 12 hr and later dried at 383 K for 90 min in hot air oven to eliminate physically adsorbed pyridine. The UV–vis spectra of xFeaCobZ catalysts were recorded in PerkinElmer UV–vis spectrophotometer (Model no: Lamda 365) in the wavelength range of 200 to 1100 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies were performed to know the chemical nature, surface composition, oxidation state of metal present in catalysts using Axis Supra spectro (Kratos Analytical) spectrometer equipped with monochromatized Al Kα source (1486.69 eV). XPSPEAK 41 software was used for deconvolution of peaks and data were processed employing Shirley background fitting funtion. The reported binding energies were referenced to binding energy of C 1 s at 284.73 eV. Temperature program reduction (H2-TPR) studies were accomplished in an AutoChem II 2920 (Micromeritics, USA) chemisorption analyser. Prior to reduction study, the fresh catalyst was heat treated at 473 K for 1 hr in flow of Ar to remove moisture and other impurities. After completion of pre-treatment, the temperature was brought down to 373 K retaining the flow of Ar. The flow of gas was changed to 10 vol% H2/Ar and the temperature was gradually raised to 1173 K using heating ramp of 10 K/min. The thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was employed for recording the consumption of hydrogen. 2.4 Catalysts activity studies Activity of catalysts for DMTM reaction was evaluated in a continuous flow fixed bed downflow stainless steel tubular reactor (1-inch ID) operated at atmospheric pressure. The powder catalyst physically mixed with inert quartz sand in the ratio of 1:4 was utilized for making the catalyst bed and the bed was placed in the isothermal zone of reactor by supporting with quartz wool from both sides. The loaded catalyst was pre-treated for 1 hr at reaction temperature under the flow of N2 (15 ml min−1) and O2 (15 ml min−1) controlled individually by thermal mass flow controller (EL-FLOW, Bronkhorst). On completion of pretreatment, the reaction gas mixture containing N2, O2, and CH4 in desired mole ratio was introduced at a total flow rate of 60 ml min−1. The gaseous products mixture unleashed from the reactor was passed through a condenser. The low boiling products were condensed and subsequently separated in a gas-liquid separator. The liquid products were collected periodically after 5 hr of reaction time. The gaseous products were directly transferred to the online micro gas chromatograph (Agilent micro GC 490) and another Gas Chromatograph (Shimadzu, Nexis GC-2030). The permanent gases in product mixture (H2, N2, O2, CH4, and CO2) were analysed using online micro-GC (Agilent 490) with µ-TCD connected to PPU (Pora plot U) and MS5A (CP-molsieve) columns, whereas the C1 C2 hydrocarbon gases were analysed using online GC (Shimadzu, Nexis GC-2030) fitted with FID (flame ionisation detector) and GS-GasPro capillary column (Agilent 30 m x 0.32 mm). The liquid product obtained were analysed using GC-FID (Agilent 7890B GC) connected to DB-WAX column (30 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 µm). The acetonitrile was used as an external standard for the quantification of liquid products. Gas chromatography mass spectroscopy (GC–MS, Shimazdu GCMS QP2010 Ultra) was used for the identification of gaseous and liquid products. Moreover, pure compounds were also used for further confirmation. Typical GC chromatograms of the products formed in gas and liquid phase are presented in Fig. S1. The carbon balance analysis for the experimental runs was performed and the estimated errors were within ± 5 %. Reproducibility of the experimental runs was ensured by performing experiments in triplicate using 20Fe1Co1Z catalyst at 873 K under identical reaction conditions (WHSV = 1030 ml hr−1 g cat−1; total volumetric flow rate: 60 ml min−1 (CH4:O2:N2 =30:15:15 ml min−1). The long duration reaction was also performed for 45 hr at optimum reaction conditions to test the catalyst stability. The conversion of CH4 and product selectivity were calculate using following equations, C H 4 Conv ersi on ( % ) = ( Init ial moles of meth ane ) − ( Final moles of meth ane ) ( Init ial moles of meth ane ) × 100 Prod uct sele ctiv ity ( % ) = n * ( moles of prod uct form ed ) ( Total moles of carb on conv erted ) × 100 Where ‘n’ is number of carbon atoms n = 1 for CH4, HCHO, HCOOH, CH3OH, CO2 and n = 2 for C2H6 and C2H4. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterisation N2 adsorption-desorption studies were performed to determine the textural properties of pure HZSM-5 and all the prepared catalysts as presented in Table 1 , Figs. 1 and S2. The HZSM-5 supported Fe catalysts showed steep N2 uptake in the relative pressure (P/Po) range of 0.9 to 1 in comparison to pure HZSM-5, which indicates the formation of mesopores [43]. The formation of mesopores was noticed on deposition of more Fe than Co in composite catalyst. The hysteresis loops are developed in the range of P/Po = 0.44 to 0.9 as depicted in Figs. 1 and S2 and the isotherms of all synthesised catalysts resembles type IV isotherm. The BET surface area and pore volume determined for all metal loaded HZSM-5 catalysts are less than the pure HZSM-5. Moreover, the micropore area of metal supported catalysts are also less compared to the pure HZSM-5. These results indicate the blockage of the micropores by the deposited Fe and Co species [6,44]. However, the pore blockage phenomena was much severe in presence of Co species than Fe species due to greater ionic radii of Co(III) species in oxide form [6]. The total pore volume of Co/HZSM-5 is lower than Fe/HZSM-5 catalyst which further confirms the previous statement and similar trend was observed in composite catalysts with the variation of the metal ratio. Previous study also suggested that pore blocking in Co/HZSM-5 catalyst can occurs by the formation of bulk species of Co oxide [45]. The micropore volume and micropore area for Fe/HZSM-5 catalysts are less as compared with pure HZSM-5 and Co/HZSM-5 suggesting that Fe species are located inside zeolite micropores [46]. Fig. S3 shows no change in pore size distribution (PSD) for pure as well as all synthesised catalyst with maxima in the microporous region. The powder XRD pattern of prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The XRD pattern of pure HZSM-5 showed characteristics diffraction peaks of HZSM-5 of MFI topology at 2θ of 14.77° (0 3 1), 23.17° (5 0 1), 23.3° (0 5 1), 23.72° (1 5 1), 23.97° (3 0 3) and 24.43° (1 3 3) [ICCD PDF card no. 00–042–0023]. The characteristic peaks of HZSM-5 remains consistent in all metal oxide impregnated catalysts. However, the intensity of peaks in the 2θ range of 22° to 25° was reduced on impregnation of metal oxides indicating loss in crystallinity of HZSM-5 [6]. The relative crystallinity of prepared catalysts calculated from XRD data are summarised in Table 1. The diffraction peaks at 2θ value of 33.26° (1 0 4), 35.72° (1 1 0), 40.98° (1 1 3), 49.58° (0 2 4), 54.18° (1 1 6), 62.54° (2 1 4) and 63.16° (3 0 0) corresponds to Fe2O3 species [ICCD PDF card no. 00–033–0664] whereas the peaks at 2θ value of 31.26° (2 2 0), 36.84° (3 1 1), 38.54° (2 2 2), 44.8° (4 0 0), 55.64° (4 2 2), 59.36° (5 1 1) and 65.22° (4 4 0) corresponds to Co3O4 species [ICCD PDF card no. 00–042–1467]. The intensity of peaks attributed to Fe2O3 and Co3O4 species increases with increasing the metal loading as shown in Fig. S4. FT-IR spectra in hydroxyl (OH) and fingerprint regions for all prepared catalysts along with pure HZSM-5 are depicted in Fig. 3 and Fig. S5A, B and C. IR spectrum of pure HZSM-5 exhibited all characteristics bands and are listed in Table S1. The IR spectrum of pure HZSM-5 in OH region exhibits bands at 3646 cm−1, 3611 cm−1 and 3434 cm−1 are attributed to the extra framework alumina with Lewis acid character, bridge hydroxyl group (Al-OH-Si) with Brønsted acid character and hydrogen bonded silanol nests, respectively [47-48]. The characteristics IR bands of pure HZSM-5 were also present in all mono metal oxide and composite catalysts suggesting preservation of zeolite framework even after deposition of metal oxides. The decline in intensity of the characteristics band at 3611 cm-1 in Fe/HZSM-5 and Co/HZSM-5 is attributed to the cationic exchange at Brønsted acid sites within the zeolite [26]. However, in case of Co/HSM-5 this decrease in intensity may also be due to the presence of Co anions in the form of CoO oxide type cluster [49]. No additional band was observed in Fe/HZSM-5 as IR band of Fe2O3 species at 540 cm−1 overlaps with the band of HZSM-5 [44]. However, a small shoulder appeared at 609 cm−1 in Fe/HZSM-5 catalysts is ascribed to Fe-O bond vibration [50]. The appearance of IR band at 667 cm−1 in Co/HZSM-5 and composite catalysts is due to Co-O stretching vibrations of Co3O4 [44,51], and the band intensity rises with increasing the cobalt content in the catalysts. FT-IR spectra of pyridine adsorbed catalysts were acquired to investigate the nature of acid sites (Brønsted and Lewis acid sites) present and are shown in Figs. 4 and S6. The IR bands observed at 1448 cm−1, 1492 cm−1 and 1546 cm−1 are due to the interaction of pyridine with Lewis acid sites (L), combined Brønsted and Lewis acid sites (B + L) and Brønsted acid sites (B), respectively [47] [52]. The deposition of metal oxides on HZSM5 decreases the Brønsted acid sites as presented in Fig 4. The intensity of IR band corresponds to Brønsted acid sites is reduced more in Co/HZSM-5 than the Fe/HZSM-5 catalysts. However, the intensity of IR band corresponds to Lewis acid sites is increased on deposition of Fe and Co oxides. Specifically, deposition of Co oxides generated more Lewis acid sites than the Fe oxides as presented in Fig. 4. UV–vis spectra of prepared catalysts are illustrated in Figs. 5 and S7B to determine the nature of Fe and Co species present in the catalysts and the spectrum of pure HZSM-5 is shown in Fig. S7A as reference. The various UV-active Fe species formed are classified as tetrahedrally coordinated isolated Fe3+ species located in zeolite framework (200–300 nm), oligomeric iron oxide clusters within zeolites channels (300–400 nm) and large iron oxide aggregates (Fe2O3) situated on the external surface of zeolite (> 400 nm) [18,26,53–55]. However, the hydroxylation of oxo bridge of binuclear Fe-oxo cluster also results in the formation of isolated Fe3+ and consequently appearance of band below 300 nm [56]. Thus, it is quite difficult to ascertain the presence of tetrahedrally coordinated isolated Fe3+ species located in zeolite framework. Only Fe and Fe-Co composite catalysts show band at a specific wavelength range. In Fe/HZSM-5, the bands appeared below 300 nm and above 400 nm are possibly because of the formation of isolated Fe3+ species in HZSM-5 framework and bulk iron oxide species on external surface of HZSM-5, respectively. The formation of bulk iron species is also confirmed by XRD as mentioned above [46]. As shown in Fig. 5 the UV–vis spectra of Co/HZSM-5 catalysts exhibited band at 459 nm and 657 nm (marked with solid circle) are assigned to the isolated Co2+species, whereas the weak band at 372 nm and broad band at 732 nm (marked with asterisk) are ascribed to the octahedral Co3+ indicating the formation of Co3O4 clusters. However, appearance of band at 503 nm (marked with circles) indicates the presence of CoO [41,57]. Furthermore, in Fe-Co/HZSM-5 composite catalysts, the band intensity rises with increasing the metal oxide loading. However, the band corresponding to isolated Co2+species at 657 nm increases for composite catalyst with 25 wt.% of total metal oxide loading. The XPS spectra of the prepared catalysts were acquired to know the electronic state of the constitute elements as shown in Fig. 6 A, B and C. The full survey spectrum of HZSM-5 shows the presence of Si(2p) and Al(2p) peak at binding energy (BE) of 103.48 eV and 75.47 eV, respectively [58]. The survey spectra of HZSM-5 and supported Fe-Co composite catalysts are shown in Fig. S8. Here, all core level peaks of the constituent elements were calibrated using the C 1 s peak (284.73 eV) as depicted in Fig. S9. As shown in Fig. 6A, the O1s spectrum of HZSM-5 shows a single peak at BE of 532.55 eV which is attribute to the lattice oxygen species [59,60]. However, the appearance of O1s peaks at BE between 529.04 eV to 529.75 eV and at BE of 530.4 eV of supported catalysts are assigned to the surface lattice oxygen (O2−) species and adsorbed oxygen species, respectively [43,59]. The ratio of lattice oxygen species to adsorbed oxygen species calculated for all the catalysts is summarised in Table 2 . and shows the maximum value for 20Fe1Co1Z catalyst. As shown in Fig. 6B, the iron loaded HZMS-5 catalysts show characteristic peaks of Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 at BE of 710 eV and 724 eV, respectively together with two corresponding shake up satellites peaks [43]. The deconvolution of core level Fe 2p3/2 peak at BE 710 eV results two peaks at BE 710.16 eV and 712.51 eV assigned to Fe2+ and Fe3+ [43,44], respectively. Similarly, the deconvolution of Fe 2p1/2 core level peak at 724 eV results two peaks attributed to Fe2+ and Fe3+ at BE of 723.77 eV and 726.91 eV, respectively [50]. The shake-up peaks of Fe3+ are appeared at 717.86 eV and 733.06 eV [61,62]. However, no shake up peaks were observed for Fe2+. The surface concentration of Fe2+ and Fe3+ species calculated from relative area of corresponding peaks shows that the concentration of Fe3+ species increases with increasing the iron loading. These results confirm very high prevalence of Fe3+ species in all prepared catalysts which is also supported by XRD and UV–vis analysis. The Fe3+species plays crucial role in CH bond activation in methane molecule which is the key step in direct conversion of methane to methanol as discussed later. The deconvoluted spectra of Co2p are shown in Fig. 6C. The deconvoluted spectra show characteristics peaks at BE of 781 eV and 795 eV corresponding to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively [44]. The deconvolution of both the peaks results peaks at BE of 781.79 eV and 798.12 eV ascribed to Co2+ species whereas peaks at BE of 780.06 eV and 795.32 eV ascribed to Co3+ species. The shake-up peaks observed at 786.48 eV and 803.19 eV are attribute to the Co3+and Co2+ species, respectively [45,59,63]. It was observed that with increase in cobalt content in catalysts, the concentration of Co2+ species increases, and this species plays a key role in tuning the selectivity of methanol. The detail peak assignment for all the catalysts is shown in Table S2. The H2-TPR studies were performed to understand the reducibility of the supported Fe-Co catalysts and the corresponding profiles are presented in Fig 7. The H2-TPR profile of pure HZSM-5 does not show any reduction peak suggesting that ZSM-5 is not reducible under the studied range of temperature. The H2-TPR profile of Fe/HZSM-5 catalyst shows three reduction peaks at temperature of 667 K, 832 K and 991 K indicating stagewise reduction of iron species. The first sharp reduction peak corresponds to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 whereas the second and third broad reductions peaks are ascribed to the subsequent reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO and then successive reduction to metallic Fe [46,64,65,66]. As shown in Fig. S10, the second and third reduction peaks are slightly shifted to the higher temperature with increasing the total metal loading from 5 wt.% to 20 wt.% of iron loading. Moreover, a significant shift in reduction temperature was noticed for 25 wt.% of total metal loading. The reposition of reduction temperature to the higher temperature is due to the increase in iron content [46] and formation of more bulk iron oxide which reduces at higher temperature [66]. A similar trend was observed for iron rich supported Fe-Co composite catalysts of varying Fe/Co metal ratio as shown in Fig. 7. On the other hand, the Co species undergoes two stage reduction in the studied temperature range. In the first stage, the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO occurs at relatively lower temperature of 662 K and then subsequent reduction of CoO species occurs at around 746 K [49,51,59]. The weak reduction peak at relatively lower temperature of 617 K is attributed to the reduction of extra framework cobalt oxide having weak interaction with support [51]. Furthermore the reduction peak at 904 K is related to the reduction of cobalt silicate and or cobalt aluminate [45]. 3.2 Reaction studies Direct methane to methanol (DMTM) reaction was investigated using pure HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 23) and oxidised HZSM-5 supported Fe, Co, and Fe-Co composite catalysts under changing process parameters such as temperature (773 −953 K), WHSV (655–1440 ml hr−1- gcat−1) and CH4/O2 mole ratio. Methanol, formaldehyde formic acid were the primary products identified in liquid phase. However, analysis of gaseous products revealed the formation of carbon dioxide as major product along with the others identified products such as hydrogen, ethane, and ethylene. The influence of various reaction parameters, total metal oxide loading and molar ratio of metals on the product distribution is discussed in the subsequent sections. 3.2.1 Effect of total metal loading The DMTM reaction was studied using supported Fe-Co catalysts of different total metal oxide loading from 5 wt.% to 25 wt.% with constant Fe/Co molar ratio of 1:1 at 873 K reaction temperature and WHSV of 1030 ml hr − 1 gcat−1. The variation of product distribution and conversion with total metal loading are presented in Figs. 8 and S11. The methane conversion was increased sharply from 28.64 % to 42.81 % with increasing the metal loading from 5 wt.% to 20 wt.% and decreased thereafter. Similar trend was observed for the conversion of oxygen and maximum oxygen conversion of 98.97 % was achieved for 20 wt.% of metal loading. The highest yield of methanol was obtained for composite catalysts with 20 wt.% of total metal loading. The methanol selectivity was found to enhance with increasing the metal loading from 5 wt.% to 20 wt.% and the highest methanol selectivity of 4.37% was achieved for 20 wt.% of total metal loading. Subsequently, the formation of formic acid and CO2 was suppressed. However, a sharp decline in selectivity of methanol was observed above 20 wt.% of total metal loading because of the overoxidation of methanol to carbon dioxide. The selectivity of formaldehyde was increased from 0.73 % to 1.24 % with the increase in total metal oxide loading from 5 wt.% to 25 wt.% indicating overoxidation of methanol. The decline in methanol selectivity and methane conversion for Fe-Co composite catalysts with 25 wt.% of total metal loading is due to the formation of bulk iron oxide species. The reposition of reduction peak to the higher temperature as shown in H2 TPR profile confirms the presence of bulk metal oxide species. On the other hand, the increased formation of formaldehyde as metal loading increases can be ascribed to the existence of more isolated Co2+ species [38,49]. UV–vis spectra show enhanced peak intensity corresponding to the isolated Co2+ species for catalyst of total metal loading above 20 wt.%. Thus, highest yield of methanol was achieved with the Fe-Co composite catalyst of total metal oxide loading 20 wt.% and was considered as an appropriate metal oxide loading for further studies. 3.2.2 Effect of metal ratio The primary challenge for producing methanol from methane is the activation of the methane molecule and suppress the over oxidation of methanol to carbon dioxide. In the present investigation, both mono metal oxide and Fe-Co composite catalysts could activate the methane molecule under the studied reaction conditions. The performance of the supported Fe-Co catalysts for DMTM are depicted in Figs. 9 and S12. The pure HZSM-5 was also studied for comparison purpose and the results are summarised in Table 3 . In comparison to pure HZSM-5, the mono metal oxide and Fe-Co composite catalysts showed higher methane and oxygen conversion suggesting that the iron and cobalt species are effective in activating methane molecule at studied reaction conditions. However, enhanced methane conversion was achieved with Fe-Co composite catalysts in comparison to mono metal oxide Fe/HZSM-5 and Co/HZSM-5 catalysts. The highest methane conversion of 42.81% was achieved for Fe-Co composite catalyst with Fe-Co molar ratio of 1:1. The complete conversion of oxygen was realized for all the catalysts. The maximum yield of methanol was obtained with the Fe-Co composite catalysts with Fe/Co molar ratio of 1:1. In case of mono metal oxide catalysts, higher yield of methanol was obtained for Fe/HZSM-5 catalyst in comparison to Co/HZSM-5 catalysts. The selectivity of methanol and other oxygenates was varied with the Fe-Co molar ratio as shown in Fig. 9. The distinct improvement in methanol selectivity was noticed for Fe-Co composite catalysts in comparison to mono metal oxide catalysts and maximum methanol selectivity was obtained for Fe-Co composite catalysts with Fe/Co molar ratio of 1:1. The selectivity of formaldehyde was increased from 0.49 % to 1.46% with the increase in cobalt content in Fe-Co composite catalysts and the highest selectivity of formaldehyde was obtained for Co/HZSM-5 catalyst. In contrast, the selectivity of formic acid was increased from 0.99% to 5.02% with the increase in Fe content in Fe-Co catalysts suggesting that Fe/HZSM-5 catalyst was more selective toward the formation formic acid. The Brønsted and Lewis acidity has influence on the selectivity of the methanol and other oxygenates. The methanol selectivity increases with the decrease in B/L ratio (Table 1 and Fig. 9) till Fe/Co molar ratio of 1:1 for 20FeaCobZ catalysts. Further increase in Co content slightly increases the B/L ratio and decreases the selectivity of methanol. Thus, Fe and Co rich 20FeaCobZ catalysts favour the formation of oxidized products such as formic acid and formaldehyde, respectively. Deposition of Fe and Co metal oxides decreases B/L ratio drastically as compared to pure HZSM5. Specifically, deposition of Co has a strong influence in decrease of B/L ratio. This enhancement in selectivity of formaldehyde with the increasing Co content in Fe-Co composite catalysts can be correlated with the increase in Co2+ species within overall Co species. As calculated from XPS data presented in Table 2, the proportion of Co2+ species within overall Co species increases in Fe-Co composite catalysts with the increase in cobalt content. Previous studies reported that the Co2+ cationic species promotes the formation of formaldehyde [38,39,41]. Thus, higher selectivity of formaldehyde for Co rich 20FeaCobZ catalysts is because of the presence of higher amount of Co2+ cationic species. The 20Fe1Co1Z composite catalysts showed highest yield of methanol with methane conversion of 42.81 % and methanol selectivity of 4.37 %. This result suggests that Fe and Co in molar ratio of 1:1 behaves synergistically in activating the CH bond in methane and simultaneously in desorbing methanol from catalysts surface which prevents deep oxidation of methanol to CO2. However, the synergistic effect of Fe-Co catalysts resulting improved catalytic performance can be correlated with the ratio of lattice to adsorbed oxygen as determined from XPS results discussed earlier. Previous study also suggests that both lattice (O2−) and adsorbed oxygen species are very much involved in partial oxidation of methane to methanol. Moreover, the adsorbed oxygen species also play an important role in methanol oxidation. Thus, tuning the lattice to adsorbed oxygen ratio appears to be critical catalyst property for achieving highest selectivity of methanol [67]. Therefore, the highest yield of methanol achieved with 20Fe1Co1Z catalyst was because of the highest lattice to adsorbed oxygen ratio. 3.2.3 Effect of temperature The reaction temperature plays a crucial role in the activation of CH bond in methane due to high thermodynamic stability of methane molecule. Requirement of high reaction temperature for methane activation also leads to the decomposition of methanol leading to the formation of overoxidized products such as HCHO, HCOOH and COx (CO and CO2) and thereby significantly affects the yield of desired product methanol. The DMTM reaction was studied in the temperature range of 773 K to 953 K at WHSV = 1030 ml hr−1 gcat−1 and CH4/O2 = 2:1 using 20Fe1Co1Z catalyst. The change in selectivity of products and conversion of methane with the reaction temperature is shown in Figs. 10 and S13. The conversion of methane was increased significantly with raising the temperature from 773 K to 873 K and maximum methane conversion of 42.81% was achieved at 873 K. The methane conversion was decreased with the rise in temperature beyond 873 K. Moreover, the oxygen conversion followed the similar trend and complete conversion of oxygen was achieved at reaction temperature of 873 K and above. The selectivity of methanol was attained a maximum value of 4.37 % at reaction temperature of 873 K and then declined with further raising the temperature, whereas the selectivity of HCOOH exhibited an increasing trend with rising the temperature. The overoxidation of methanol to formic acid and CO2 causes the drop in methanol selectivity at temperatures above 873 K. The higher selectivity of formic acid at high temperature (above 823 K) was due to the rapid transformation of methanol to formic acid. The resulted formic acid adsorbs molecularly on the catalyst surface and or through the formation formate species (monodentate and bidentate) [68]. At high coverage, molecularly adsorbed formic acid forms a complex with the monodentate form of formate species which provides additional stability to formic acid in comparison to pure formic acid. The complex of formic acid and monodentate formate decomposes at high temperature resulting in the formation of formic acid in gas-phase and bidentate formate species which is further converted to CO2. In our studies formic acid and CO2 might have formed following similar mechanism. However, detailed studies are required to confirm the mechanistic aspect of the formation of formic acid with higher selectivity at high temperature and can be considered as future scope of studies. 3.2.4 Effect of WHSV The effect of WHSV on product selectivity and methane conversion was studied and presented in Figs. 11 and S14. The methane conversion and selectivity of methanol attained maximum value at 1030 ml hr−1 gcat−1 of WHSV resulting in maximum yield of methanol. It was observed that the cumulative oxygenates (CH3OH, HCOOH, HCHO) selectivity increases with decreasing the WHSV. Further oxidation of formaldehyde and decomposition of formic acid leads to the formation of CO2. The increase in selectivity of formaldehyde and formic acid with decrease in WHSV results in suppression of selectivity of CO2. The higher selectivity of formic acid indicates a higher rate of its formation and stability. As discussed above, the higher stability of the formic acid is due to formation of complex of formic acid and monodentate formate species as discussed earlier. Thus the additional stability achieved due to the formation of complex of formic acid and monodentate formates might be the reason for the suppression of CO2 selectivity as the WHSV decreases. 3.2.5 Effect of CH4/O2 ratio Methane to oxygen ratio plays a vital role in the variation of product distribution. The effect of CH4/O2 ratio was examined in the range of (CH4/O2 = 3:1, 2:1, 1:1 and 1:2) and the variation of selectivity of C1 oxygenates are presented in Figs. 12 and S15. It was observed that methane conversion increases with decreasing CH4/O2 ratio meaning increasing the oxygen concentration. However, the methanol selectivity follows the opposite trend meaning decreases with the increase in oxygen concentration due to the overoxidation of methanol. The similar observations are previously reported [69,70]. The highest yield of methanol was obtained at stoichiometric CH4/O2 ratio of 2:1. The selectivity of oxygenates was increased with increasing the CH4/O2 ratio suggesting that higher CH4/O2 ratio (meaning lower concentration of oxygen) is beneficial for suppressing the deep oxidation of methanol to CO2. Moreover, the selectivity of formaldehyde increases with the decrease in CH4/O2 ratio suggesting the formation of formaldehyde is faster than the oxidation of formaldehyde leading the formation of formic acid or formic acid may also decomposes rapidly. The performance of the studied catalyst is also compared with the performance of various catalysts employed for DMTM reaction presented in Table 4 . The activity of catalysts in present investigation suggests the synergistic effects between Fe and Co oxides for DMTM resulting in improved methane conversion and overall yield of methanol than respective mono metal oxide catalysts as reported in literature. However, the improved yield of methanol was obtained at relatively lower reaction temperature and atmospheric pressure in comparison to studies conducted using batch reactor at high methane pressure. Moreover, bridging the gap for this robust selectivity-conversion trade-off for partial oxidation of methane to methanol is utmost important and needed further studies. 3.2.6 Stability study The stability of catalyst over long period of reaction time was examined by subjecting the catalyst for DMTM reaction for 45 hr and the performance of the catalyst are shown in Figs. 13 and S16. It was observed that the selectivity of methanol attained the maximum value at 10 hr and after 15 hr the selectivity of methanol decreased. Moreover, the conversion of methane showed a decreasing trend and remained unchanged after 30 hr. The yield of methanol attained maximum value at 5 hr and decreases further with the progress of reaction. These results indicate partial deactivation of the catalyst under studied reaction conditions. The spent catalyst collected after 45 hr of time on stream investigation was characterized by XRD, FTIR and XPS as shown in Figs S17, S18A and B and 14 . The decrease in catalyst activity and selectivity of products are correlated with the characterization results to delineate the catalyst deactivation. The XRD pattern of spent catalyst shows decrease in intensity of characteristic peaks of ZSM-5 as compared to fresh catalyst indicating loss in crystallinity. The diffraction peaks corresponding to Fe2O3 at 2θ of 33.26°, 40.98 o, 49.58 o, and to Co3O4 at 2θ of 31.26°, 59.36 o, 65.22° were disappeared suggesting loss of these surface metal oxides and or decomposition of these oligomeric metal oxide species. The oligomeric metal oxides Fe2O3, and Co3O4 are active surface metal oxides for DMTM reaction [38]. However, the new diffraction peaks appeared at 2θ values of 26.72°, 27.52°, 43.32° and 57.28° are attributed to the carbide species of Fe and or Co [ICCD PDF card no. 00–003–0400] [ICCD PDF card no. 00–005–0704]. The IR spectrum of spent catalyst in the fingerprint region show decrease in the intensity of both the bands at 609 cm−1 and 667 cm−1 ascribed to the Fe-O stretching bond vibration of Fe2O3 and Co-O bond stretching vibrations of Co3O4, respectively indicating loss of these surface metal oxide species as shown in Fig 18A and B. Moreover, the O1s XPS spectrum of spent catalyst shows decrease in lattice oxygen species peak which results significant decrease in lattice to adsorbed oxygen ratio as summarized in Table S3 compared to fresh catalyst. As discussed earlier, the adsorbed oxygen plays a crucial role in overoxidation of methanol leading to the formation of CO2. During 45 hr of time on stream, the selectivity of methanol gradually decreases after 5 hr and increases the selectivity of overoxidation product carbon dioxide as shown in Fig. 13. Whereas the decrease in selectivity of formaldehyde can be attributed to the reduction in proportion of Co2+species as depicted in Table S3. As shown in Fig. S19A and B, the Co2p and Fe2p XPS spectra of spent catalyst indicate the reduction in intensity of the characteristic peaks compared to the fresh catalyst. The reduction in proportion of Fe3+species in spent catalyst as compared to fresh catalyst limits the conversion of methane as Fe3+ species plays a crucial role in the CH bond activation of methane. Moreover, the poisoning of the catalyst by secondary products (formaldehyde and formic acid) also reduces the activity of the catalyst by blocking the active sites over long hours of reaction. 4 Conclusion The present investigation demonstrated the catalytic performance of Fe and Co mono metal oxide and composite catalysts supported over HZSM-5 for the direct conversion of methane to methanol in one step in a fixed bed reactor under changing process parameters such as temperature, weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) and CH4/O2 ratio. The influence of various reaction parameters, total metal loading and molar ratio of metals on product distribution were also discussed. A comprehensive characterization of Fe-Co/HZSM5 catalysts prepared by wet impregnation method revealed the presence of various iron and cobalt species depending on the molar ratio of Fe-Co The formation of respective bulk metal oxide species, Fe2O3 and Co3O4 was noticed for higher metal loading catalysts from XRD and H2 TPR results. Moreover, the XPS and UV–vis spectroscopic results confirmed the presence of both Fe2+/Fe3+ and Co2+/Co3+ species and relative concentration of these species was different depending on the Fe-Co molar ratio. The catalytic activity of Fe-Co composite catalysts was proved more effective for the activation of methane leading to the formation of methanol at reaction temperatures of 773 K and above. The surface concentration of Co2+ species was found to have a direct correlation with the activity of Fe-Co composite catalysts as it favours the formation of formaldehyde. In contrast, high iron content in Fe-Co composite catalysts promotes the formation of formic acid. Additionally, the lattice-to-adsorbed oxygen ratio also played a crucial role in improving the selectivity of methanol. The adsorbed oxygen favours the overoxidation of methanol. Thus, 20Fe1Co1Z with the highest lattice to adsorbed oxygen ratio found to be the best performing catalysts and maximum yield of methanol (1.87%) was obtained with this Fe-Co composite catalysts at given reaction conditions [temperature = 873 K; WHSV = 1030 ml hr−1 gcat−1 and CH4/O2 = 2:1] in the present investigation. Moreover, the reaction temperature higher than 873 K favours overoxidation of methanol resulting in the formation of HCOOH and CO2. The catalyst stability studies revealed partial deactivation of catalyst at higher time on stream. The primary reason for the deactivation of the catalyst was due to the loss of active surface metal oxides species, loss of crystallinity and deposition of carbonaceous species. coredata.dc:description: The direct conversion of methane to methanol over iron and cobalt oxide based composite catalysts supported over HZSM-5 was carried out in a fixed-bed micro reactor under changing process parameters and catalyst compositions. The prepared catalysts were well characterized by various techniques including N2 adsorption desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), pyridine FTIR, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), UV–vis spectroscopy and temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR). The characterization results revealed the presence of various reducible iron and cobalt oxide species depending on the Fe/Co molar ratio and total metal oxide loading. Moreover, the XPS and UV–vis spectroscopic results also confirmed the variation of Fe2+/Fe3+ and Co2+/Co3+ species depending on the Fe-Co molar ratio which had strong influence on the performance of the composite catalysts. It was found that the cobalt species favours the formaldehyde formation whereas the iron species promotes the formic acid formation in their respective pure supported oxide catalysts. However, the synergistic effect of iron and cobalt oxide in equimolar ratio in composite catalysts appeared as effective for achieving highest yield of methanol. The methanol selectivity was also influenced by the alteration of various studied process parameters. The higher reaction temperature favoured the overoxidation of methanol to CO2 whereas the methanol selectivity increased with increasing the methane to oxygen ratio. The lattice to adsorbed oxygen ratio also had strong influence on the activity of composite catalysts and methanol selectivity. The highest methanol yield of 1.87% was achieved at the methane conversion of 42.81 % with the 20Fe1Co1Z catalyst at 873 K reaction temperature with CH4/O2 ratio of 2:1 and WHSV of 1030 ml hr−1 gcat−1.
coredata.dc:title: Synergy between Fe-Co oxide catalysts supported over HZSM-5 for direct conversion of methane to methanol
